wikipedia_page.main: Mary Adela Blagg  (17 May 1858 – 14 April 1944) was an English astronomer and was elected a fellow of the Royal Astronomical Society in 1916.

response: In 1919 the IAU was formed, and it appointed a committee to regularize the chaotic lunar and Martian nomenclatures then current. Much of the work was done by Mary Adela Blagg, and the report Named Lunar Formations by Blagg and Muller (1935), was the first systematic listing of lunar nomenclature. Later, "The System of Lunar Craters, quadrants I, II, III, IV" was published, under the direction of Gerard P. Kuiper. These works were adopted by the IAU and became the recognized sources for lunar nomenclature.

Blagg is a tiny lunar impact crater located on the Sinus Medii. It is a circular crater with no appreciable erosion. To the east-southeast is the irregular crater Rhaeticus, and northeast lies Triesnecker.  It is about 33 km to the east of the slightly larger Bruce. It was named after noted English astronomer Mary Adela Blagg. Its diameter is 5.0 km.

The crater was named after the Hungarian astronomer and an ordained Jesuit priest Maximilian Hell (1720–1792). The name was first given by Johann Hieronymus Schröter to the entire plane, Hell plane, which is now known as Deslandres, but Mädler reassigned it to the crater.Ewen A. Whitaker Mapping and Naming the Moon: A History of Lunar Cartography and Nomenclature, Cambridge University Press, 2004, , pp. 123, 218 It was officially recognized by Mary Adela Blagg and Karl Müller in the first official version of the International Astronomical Union (IAU) nomenclature for lunar features in 1935.Mordechai Feingold History of Universities, Volume 24, Oxford University Press, 2010,  p. 184Mary Adela Blagg, William Henry Wesley Named lunar formations, Volume 1, P. Lund, Humphries, 1935 Hell B was previously known as Schupmann and Hell Q as Cassini's Bright Spot.

response: He collaborated with Mary Adela Blagg on standardizing the nomenclature of formations on the Moon for the Lunar Commission of the newly formed International Astronomical Union. Together with Blagg he produced a two volume set in 1935, entitled Named Lunar Formations, that became the standard reference on the subject.
*Mary Adela Blagg (1858–1944) was an English astronomer who during her life did a lot of volunteer work, including caring for Belgian refugee children during World War I.
